title: Chinese government provides fourth phase of technical assistance project to the Presidential Palace of Togo and Lomé Hospital in May 2020
description: On May 13, 2020, the Chinese government provided a fourth phase of technical assistance to the Presidential Palace of Togo and Lomé Hospital. The specific actions involved in this assistance, and the monetary value of this provision, are unknown.  A ceremony was held for the signing of the handover certificate for this assistance. Chao Weidong, the Chinese Ambassador to Togo, Victoire Tomega-Dobe, the Chief of Staff of the President of Togo, and the Minister of Health and Public Health in Togo, Tafa Miguiawa, signed the handover certificate for the aid to the Presidential Palace of Togo and the Lomé Hospital.
combined_text:

Chao Weidong, the Chinese Ambassador to Togo, Victoire Tomega-Dobe, the Chief of Staff of the President of Togo, and the Minister of Health and Public Health in Togo, Tafa Miguiawa, signed the handover certificate for the aid to the Presidential Palace of Togo and the Lomé Hospital.
justification: Project focuses on technical assistance for healthcare facilities without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Technical assistance to hospital and presidential palace, healthcare sector focus

title: China Merchants Group provides anti-epidemic materials to LCT Terminal in Togo in March 2020
description: In March of 2020, ​​China Merchants Group provided a batch of anti-epidemic materials to Lomé Container Terminal in Lomé, Togo. The specific content and monetary value of this donation are unknown.  China Merchants Group has provided 6.72 million masks, more than 2.32 million sets of protective clothing, 100,000 eye protection products, and 7.57 million pairs of gloves, 7 containers to support the construction of centralized treatment centers for infectious diseases, and 700 negative pressure monitoring ambulances for customs clearance to countries worldwide.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China Merchants Group provides anti-epidemic materials to LCT Terminal in Togo in March 2020

# Description
In March of 2020, ​​China Merchants Group provided a batch of anti-epidemic materials to Lomé Container Terminal in Lomé, Togo. The specific content and monetary value of this donation are unknown.  China Merchants Group has provided 6.72 million masks, more than 2.32 million sets of protective clothing, 100,000 eye protection products, and 7.57 million pairs of gloves, 7 containers to support the construction of centralized treatment centers for infectious diseases, and 700 negative pressure monitoring ambulances for customs clearance to countries worldwide.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies and equipment for epidemic response, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Anti-epidemic materials including masks, protective clothing, eye protection, gloves, and ambulances provided for healthcare purposes

title: Chinese Government Donates Medical Supplies to Tongan Ministry of Health to fight Covid-19 (linked to project #93605)
description: According to a press release by the Tongan government, on May 19th, 2020 the Chinese government donated medical supplies to the Ministry of Health to aid their fight against the Covid-19 pandemic. The list of supplies donated included 100 infrared thermometers, 500 diagnostic kits, 2,700 medical disposable protective garments, 1,000 surgical shoe covers, 2,000 disposable rubber surgical gloves, 1,000 medical disposable face shields, 1,500 protective goggles, 74,700 face masks and 260 units of hand sanitizer gel.   The handover ceremony took place at the Vaiola hospital in Nukuʻalofa, Tonga. In attendance were Chinese ambassador to Tonga, Cao Xiaolin, and Tongan Minister for Health Dr. Amelia Afuha’amango Tu’ipulotu. The donation of the medical supplies was accompanied by a concurrent donation of US$250,000 from the China – Pacific Island Countries Joint COVID-19 Response Fund (see project #93605).
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:

title: Government of China donates computers and projectors to Tonga to assist women's empowerment
description: On July 20th, the Ambassador of the People's Republic of China in Tonga, Cao Xiaolin, presided over a handover of communications equipment to the Tongan Minister for Internal Affairs, Vatau Hui. The donation consisted of 30 laptop computers and laptop bags, 3 computer mice and 2 portable projectors. The  equipment was donated by the All-China Women's Federation and is to go to the Tongan Ministry of Internal Affairs, Women’s Affairs and Gender Equality Division. According to the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the computers are to be used for "capacity building through trainings for the purpose of improving local women’s working skills". The donation came after the Ministry of Internal Affairs applied for a grant.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
Government of China donates computers and projectors to Tonga to assist women's empowerment

# Description
On July 20th, the Ambassador of the People's Republic of China in Tonga, Cao Xiaolin, presided over a handover of communications equipment to the Tongan Minister for Internal Affairs, Vatau Hui. The donation consisted of 30 laptop computers and laptop bags, 3 computer mice and 2 portable projectors. The  equipment was donated by the All-China Women's Federation and is to go to the Tongan Ministry of Internal Affairs, Women’s Affairs and Gender Equality Division. According to the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the computers are to be used for "capacity building through trainings for the purpose of improving local women’s working skills". The donation came after the Ministry of Internal Affairs applied for a grant.
justification: Project focuses on social development and capacity building without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of computers and projectors for women's empowerment and capacity building

title: Guangdong Province donates fishing boats and tractors to Tongan Ministry of Fisheries
description: According to a press release by the Tongan Ministry of Fisheries (MoF), on October 8th, 2020 China's Ambassador to Tonga, Cao Xiaolin, oversaw the handover of eight fishing boats and nine tractors to the Tongan Ministry of Fisheries and the Tongan Ministry of Agriculture in Maúfanga.   The boats were donated by the Ocean and Fishery Bureau of Dongguan Municipal People’s Government, and are to assist in the Tongan Ministry of Fisheries in the ministry's work in the fishery sector. According to the Tonga Broadcasting Commission, the Tongan government made the request for fishing boats in 2018. The government of Dongguan city then provided TP$643,924.99 for the  manufacturing of the eight fishing boats and outboard engines in Tonga. The fishing boats will be divided among the outer islands of Tonga, with four to go to Ha'apai to fulfill the sister city relationship between Dongguan and Ha’apai.   According to the MoF press release, the tractors were provided by the Beijing Machinery Repair Company Limited of China. According to the Chinese embassy, Guangdong province was the main entity behind both the fishing boats and the tractors, meaning the tractors were likely also donated by Dongguang. A later press release from the Tongan Ministry of Agriculture states the tractors were donated by the Chinese government.  The Tongan CEO of Agriculture, Dr Viliami Manu, says the tractors will be rentable by the Tongan public for $80 pa’anga per hour.  These donations are not the first time that China has donated agricultural equipment to Tonga, and China's Ambassador to Tonga remarked at the handover ceremony that previous donations have improved agricultural productivity.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Guangdong Province donates fishing boats and tractors to Tongan Ministry of Fisheries

# Description
According to a press release by the Tongan Ministry of Fisheries (MoF), on October 8th, 2020 China's Ambassador to Tonga, Cao Xiaolin, oversaw the handover of eight fishing boats and nine tractors to the Tongan Ministry of Fisheries and the Tongan Ministry of Agriculture in Maúfanga.   The boats were donated by the Ocean and Fishery Bureau of Dongguan Municipal People’s Government, and are to assist in the Tongan Ministry of Fisheries in the ministry's work in the fishery sector. According to the Tonga Broadcasting Commission, the Tongan government made the request for fishing boats in 2018. The government of Dongguan city then provided TP$643,924.99 for the  manufacturing of the eight fishing boats and outboard engines in Tonga. The fishing boats will be divided among the outer islands of Tonga, with four to go to Ha'apai to fulfill the sister city relationship between Dongguan and Ha’apai.   According to the MoF press release, the tractors were provided by the Beijing Machinery Repair Company Limited of China. According to the Chinese embassy, Guangdong province was the main entity behind both the fishing boats and the tractors, meaning the tractors were likely also donated by Dongguang. A later press release from the Tongan Ministry of Agriculture states the tractors were donated by the Chinese government.  The Tongan CEO of Agriculture, Dr Viliami Manu, says the tractors will be rentable by the Tongan public for $80 pa’anga per hour.  These donations are not the first time that China has donated agricultural equipment to Tonga, and China's Ambassador to Tonga remarked at the handover ceremony that previous donations have improved agricultural productivity.
justification: Project involves donation of agricultural and fishing equipment for public use, with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Fishing boats and tractors donated for public use, aimed at supporting agriculture and fisheries sectors

title: Guangdong Provincial People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries donates 1,000 school bags to Tongan Primary Schools
description: On March 20th, 2020, the Tonga-China Friendship Association presided over a donation of 1,000 schoolbags to Tongan primary schools. The schoolbags were donated by the Guangdong Provincial People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, an organization funded by the Guangdong Provincial Government.  Each bag contained 2 notebooks and a pencil case with a pencil, sharpener, and eraser. The bags went to schools in Mu'a Village, Haveluliku Village, Fua'amotu Village and schools on the islands of Vava'u, 'Eua and Ha'apai.   Several donation ceremonies were held at schools for the bags- in attendance at many of the ceremonies was Chinese ambassador to Tonga, Cao Xiaolin. The donation was meant to reinforce the friendship between China and Tonga by providing supplies for primary school students.
combined_text:

# Description
On March 20th, 2020, the Tonga-China Friendship Association presided over a donation of 1,000 schoolbags to Tongan primary schools. The schoolbags were donated by the Guangdong Provincial People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, an organization funded by the Guangdong Provincial Government.  Each bag contained 2 notebooks and a pencil case with a pencil, sharpener, and eraser. The bags went to schools in Mu'a Village, Haveluliku Village, Fua'amotu Village and schools on the islands of Vava'u, 'Eua and Ha'apai.   Several donation ceremonies were held at schools for the bags- in attendance at many of the ceremonies was Chinese ambassador to Tonga, Cao Xiaolin. The donation was meant to reinforce the friendship between China and Tonga by providing supplies for primary school students.
justification: Project focuses on educational supplies donation without direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of school bags and supplies to primary schools, educational focus

title: Chinese Government Donates $250,000 USD to Tongan Ministry of Health for Coronavirus Response (linked to project #90150)
description: On May 19th, 2020, according to a press release from the Tongan government, the Chinese government donated $250,000 USD to the Tongan Ministry of Health for COVID-19 response. The donation was in the name of the China – Pacific Island Countries Joint COVID-19 Response Fund. The donation was presented by Chinese Ambassador Cao Xiaolin, to Tongan Minister for Health Dr. Amelia Afuha’amango Tu’ipulotu, at Vaiola Hospital in Nukuʻalofa, Tonga.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 73 million grant for Heavy Machinery Equipment Project
description: In 2020, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 73 million (TOP $26 million) grant to the Government of the Kingdom of Tonga for the Heavy Machinery Equipment Project. The purpose of the project was to support the Government of the Kingdom of Tonga’s road construction efforts by providing 119 pieces of heavy machinery, including rollers, loaders, excavators, bulldozers, tractors, and trucks. The equipment was officially handed over to the local authorities on February 11, 2022.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 73 million grant for Heavy Machinery Equipment Project

# Description
In 2020, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 73 million (TOP $26 million) grant to the Government of the Kingdom of Tonga for the Heavy Machinery Equipment Project. The purpose of the project was to support the Government of the Kingdom of Tonga’s road construction efforts by providing 119 pieces of heavy machinery, including rollers, loaders, excavators, bulldozers, tractors, and trucks. The equipment was officially handed over to the local authorities on February 11, 2022.
justification: Project focuses on providing heavy machinery for road construction without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of 119 pieces of heavy machinery for road construction, no specific energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant for Mala'ekula Royal Tomb Upgrade Project
description: In 2020, the Chinese Government provided an 10 million grant to the Government of Tonga for the Mala'ekula Royal Tomb Upgrade Project. Then, in June 2022, the two government signed an 'Agreement for the Peripheral Area of Mala'ekula Royal Tomb Improvement Project’. As of late 2022, there was evidence that the project had commenced.

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Tonga in 2020
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Tonga signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020). Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between May 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension is RMB 20,973,757. At the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. The lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place in equal, successive, and semi-annual installments during a 4-year repayment period after an unknown grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period). Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Tonga. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Tonga secured from the Chinese Government in 2020 (as recorded by the Government of Tonga via http://mail.finance.gov.to/sites/default/files/2022-11/Public%20Accounts%202020-2021%20en.pdf). 3. According to a February 2021 Monetary Policy Statement released by the National Reserve Bank of Tonga, ‘[China Eximbank] has deferred the principal loan repayments due on both the Tonga National Road Improvement Projects Loan and the Nuku’alofa CBD Reconstruction Project Loan from FY2020-21 to FY2021-22 under the G20’s Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI).' The Government of Tonga’s Fiscal Year runs from July 1 to June 30. Therefore, FY2020 corresponds to July 1, 2019 to June 30, 2020, FY2021 corresponds to July 1, 2020 to June 30, 2021, and FY2022 corresponds to July 1, 2021 to June 30, 2022. 4.  According to an August 2021 Monetary Policy Statement released by the National Reserve Bank of Tonga, ‘it is estimated that around $14.6 million will be suspended under the DSSI agreement with [China Eximbank]’.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Tonga in 2020

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Tonga signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020). Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between May 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension is RMB 20,973,757. At the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. The lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place in equal, successive, and semi-annual installments during a 4-year repayment period after an unknown grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period). Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt suspension agreement is a financial arrangement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt service suspension, financial terms and conditions, no specific project or environmental focus mentioned
